   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 44 year old female with cirrhosis presumed secondary to
   alcoholism and acetaminophen use, here with anemia, jaundice, and
   altered mental status.
   .
   # Altered mental status. Waxing and [**Doctor Last Name 282**]. Likely hepatic
   encephalopathy and SBP. Initially was hyponatremic on presentation, now
   persistently hypernatremic.
   - Head CT on [**3-13**] neg for acute intracranial process. Consider repeat
   head CT if suspect cerebral edema in setting of fulminant liver failure
   - Continue lactulose and rifaxamin (currently stooling well)
   - Treat hypernatremia as below
   .
   # SBP: Received Unasyn x 3 days at OSH for SBP Prophylaxis. Started
   Ceftriaxone upon arrival here. S/P diagnostic paracentesis - Second tap
   showed incr WBC with L shift, changed CTX to Zosyn on [**3-15**], per
   informal ID recs.  Bladder pressure elevated on morning of [**3-20**], pt
   increasingly uncomfortable and dyspneic.  Therapeutic para done [**2-20**] to
   remove 2.5L grossly bloody fluid.
   - Cultures NGTD. F/U pending Cx.
   .
   # Anemia: Likely multifactorial. Baseline anemia of chronic disease,
   low grade GI bleed (stools guaiac pos, not grossly bloody), and
   evidence of intraperitoneal bleeding on paracentesis, CT scan. Unlikely
   that the patient has DIC/hemolysis, since lab data underwhelming - low
   retic index, direct bilirubinemia, normal LDH, normal haptoglobin.
   Patient dropped hct again on [**3-19**] and received 4 more units of PRBCs.
   Per surgery, not operative candidate. Received 2U PRBCs, 4U FFP, 1plt
   yesterday/overnight.
   - q6h Hct/INR check.
   - Will treat supportively with blood products. Goal Hct is 21 if
   stable, will titrate transfusions if responding appropriately to blood.
   Will also treat with aggressive FFP transfusions to curtail bleeding.
   - Appreciate liver recs; EGD if evidence of brisk GIB
   - F/U peritoneal amylase level for pancreatitis /intestinal
   perforation.
   - Will re-discuss with surgery as patient continues to bleed despite
   aggressive medical tx x 3days.
   .
   # Cirrhosis / hyperbilirubinemia / [**Month/Year (2) 4182**] [**Month/Year (2) 4244**] thrombosis. Patient w/
   mild transaminitis (stable) with stable thrombocytopenia, ascites, LE
   edema, hepatosplenomegaly, and elevated INR.  This is likely secondary
   to cirrhosis from alcoholism with embarrassment by chronic
   acetaminophen use.  Currently not drinking for 1 month per patient and
   husband. [**Name (NI) **] [**Name2 (NI) 4244**] thrombosis seems acute due to no collateral flow
   in the [**Name2 (NI) 4182**] circulation on CT. EGD deferred by GI (feels anemia more
   likely due to hemolysis)
   - Follow liver enzymes
 bilirubin stable to decreasing
   - minimize non-essential meds
   - appreciate liver recs: continue lactulose, rifaximin, octreotide and
   midodrine. Pt completed 2 days of albumin infusion and steroids were
   stopped per hepatology.
   .
   # Acute renal failure. Cr trended up from 0.8 to peak of 3.0. FENa <1%,
   thus pre-renal due to hypovolemia (large stool output) or hepatorenal
   syndrome. Cr improved after albumin infusion, which argues against
   HRS.
   - Trend Cr
   - Renally dose meds.
   - Holding albumin per hepatology.
   .
   #  Thrombocytopenia. Improving. Likely secondary to liver failure and
   splenomegaly.  Evaluation for TTP and DIC will be difficult to
   interpret with liver failure.  Rare schistocytes on smear with elevated
   PTT, low fibrinogen, and direct hyperbilirubinemia.  However, LDH
   normal, arguing against TMA. E. coli O175:H7 neg argues against
   TTP/HUS. Received 1U platelets overnight.
   - Follow plt count and transfuse if plt < 10 or as needed to control
   abdominal bleeding
   .
   # Hypernatremia after initial hyponatremia: Initial hypoNa likely
   secondary to ascites and LE edema. Suspect pt became hyperNa due to TF.
   - Mix meds in D5W
   - Increase free water flushes to 300cc Q4hrs.
   - Recheck Na this afternoon and consider starting D5W if Na not fully
   corrected by then.
   .
   #.  LE edema.  Stable. B/l LE pitting edema almost certainly related to
   liver failure, as TTE did not show definitive etiology.
   #.  H/o alcohol abuse. Completed 5 days of high dose thiamine.
   - continue multivitamins, folate
   - SW consult when mental status improves
   .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, TF per nutrition recs, ISS
   .
   Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots (no HSQ given elevated INR and
   thrombocytopenia).
   .
   Access: PIV, PICC (placed [**3-19**])
   .
   Code: DNR/DNI
   .
   Communication: Patient, Husband [**Name (NI) 117**]
   Health [**Name (NI) 232**] Proxy [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) **] [**Name (NI) 4794**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 4795**] (h), [**Telephone/Fax (1) 4796**] (w)
   .
   Disposition: ICU for now; to [**Doctor Last Name 2572**]/[**Doctor Last Name **] when ready

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

- The patient is a 44-year-old female with cirrhosis presumed secondary to alcoholism and acetaminophen use.
- She presented with anemia, jaundice, and altered mental status.
- The patient has been experiencing altered mental status, likely due to hepatic encephalopathy and spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP).
- She received Unasyn for SBP prophylaxis and ceftriaxone upon arrival at the ICU.
- A therapeutic paracentesis was performed to remove 2.5L of grossly bloody fluid due to elevated bladder pressure and discomfort.
- The patient has evidence of intraperitoneal bleeding on paracentesis and CT scan.
- She has been receiving blood products and fresh frozen plasma (FFP) transfusions due to ongoing bleeding and a goal hemoglobin (Hct) of 21.
- The patient has mild transaminitis (stable), stable thrombocytopenia, ascites, lower extremity edema, hepatosplenomegaly, and elevated INR.
- She has a history of alcohol abuse and completed 5 days of high-dose thiamine.
- The patient's renal function has improved after albumin infusion, which argues against hepatorenal syndrome (HRS).
- Her thrombocytopenia is improving and is likely secondary to liver

Summary:
The patient is a 44-year-old female with cirrhosis, presumed secondary to alcoholism, presenting with anemia, jaundice, and altered mental status. She has been diagnosed with hepatic encephalopathy and spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). The patient underwent a therapeutic paracentesis to remove 2.5 liters of grossly bloody fluid due to elevated bladder pressure and discomfort. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's altered mental status is likely due to hepatic encephalopathy, a complication of liver cirrhosis. Treatment includes lactulose and rifaximin.
2. Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP): The patient has developed SBP, which is a bacterial infection of the ascitic fluid. She received ceftriaxone and later switched to Zosyn, an antibiotic recommended by infectious disease consultants. Cultures are pending.
3. Anemia: The patient has anemia that is likely multifactorial, including baseline anemia of chronic disease, low-grade gastrointestinal bleeding, and evidence of intraperitoneal bleeding. Blood products, including packed red blood cells (PRBCs), fresh frozen plasma (FFP), and platelets, have been transfused to manage the anemia and control bleeding.
4. Acute renal failure: The patient has acute renal failure with a peak creatinine level of 3.0. The cause is likely

The patient has been diagnosed with cirrhosis, likely secondary to alcoholism, and is showing signs of hepatic encephalopathy and spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP).

The patient underwent therapeutic paracentesis due to elevated bladder pressure and removal of grossly bloody fluid. Cultures were obtained from the NG tube and pending. The patient's anemia is multifactorial, including baseline anemia of chronic disease, low-grade gastrointestinal bleeding, and evidence of intraperitoneal bleeding. The patient received blood products, including red blood cells, fresh frozen plasma, and platelets.

The patient also has hypernatremia, which may be related to tube feeds. Hyponatremia was initially present but has now resolved. The patient's renal function is impaired, with a creatinine level peaking at 3.0. The patient's thrombocytopenia is improving and is likely secondary to liver failure and splenomegaly.

Other issues include lower extremity edema, which is likely related to liver failure, and a history of alcohol abuse. The patient has completed high-dose thiamine therapy.

Prophylactic measures have been taken for pneumonia, deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcers, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The

Summary:
The patient is a 44-year-old female with a history of cirrhosis, presumed secondary to alcoholism and acetaminophen use. She presents with anemia, jaundice, and altered mental status. The patient has had multiple complications including spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB), acute renal failure, thrombocytopenia, and hypernatremia.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's altered mental status may be due to hepatic encephalopathy, a complication of liver failure.
2. SBP: The patient has developed SBP, which is a bacterial infection of the ascitic fluid. It can lead to sepsis if not treated promptly.
3. GIB: There is evidence of low-grade gastrointestinal bleeding, which could be related to portal hypertension or esophageal varices.
4. Acute renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine levels indicate acute renal failure, which could be caused by hypovolemia or hepatorenal syndrome.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has low platelet counts, likely due to liver failure and splenomegaly.
6. Hypernatremia: The patient initially had hyponatremia but has now developed hypernatremia. This could be due to free water loss through diarrhea or TF.
7. Ascites: The patient has tense abdomen with distention

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 44-year-old female with a history of cirrhosis, admitted with decompensated liver failure and transient acute renal failure. She has shown rapid improvement with volume support and continued treatment for Hepatic Venous Hypertension (HRS). The current issue is persistent anemia secondary to blood loss during paracentesis, with a CT scan indicating intra-peritoneal bleeding from a parietal vessel. The patient has a coagulopathy related to underlying liver disease and has received 3 units of transfusion per day. Surgery has been consulted but declined surgical intervention at this time. The patient's coagulopathy is being managed with fresh frozen plasma (FFP), but minimal change in bleeding rate has been observed. The plan is to discuss possible interventions to stabilize the bleeding with surgery and explore an exploratory laparotomy if necessary. The risk of surgery is excessive due to the risk of recurrent or persistent bleeding following intervention. Normalization of coagulation is being attempted. The patient also has cirrhosis, acute renal failure, and hepatic encephalopathy, which are being managed accordingly. The patient's respiratory status has improved with paracentesis.

   - Cultures NGTD. F/U pending Cx.

   low grade GI bleed (stools guaiac pos, not grossly bloody), and
   evidence of intraperitoneal bleeding on paracentesis, CT scan. Unlikely
   that the patient has DIC/hemolysis, since lab data underwhelming - low

   - continue multivitamins, folate

3. Anemia: The patient likely has a multifactorial anemia, including baseline anemia of chronic disease, low-grade gastrointestinal bleeding, and evidence of intraperitoneal bleeding on paracentesis and CT scan. It is unlikely that the patient has disseminated intravascular coagulation/hemolysis, as lab data does not support this.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 44-year-old female with a history of presumed secondary cirrhosis due to alcoholism and acetaminophen use. She presents with anemia, jaundice, and altered mental status. The patient has been diagnosed with hepatic encephalopathy and spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). She has also been found to have hypernatremia, likely due to transudative fluid loss.

The patient's current medical conditions include cirrhosis, hyperbilirubinemia, thrombosis, anemia, acute renal failure, thrombocytopenia, LE edema, and a history of alcohol abuse. She is currently being treated for hepatic encephalopathy with lactulose and rifaximin. SBP prophylaxis with ceftriaxone has been initiated. The patient's anemia is multifactorial, including baseline anemia of chronic disease, low-grade gastrointestinal bleeding, and evidence of intraperitoneal bleeding. Blood product transfusions have been given to increase the patient's hematocrit level.

The patient's renal function is compromised, with acute renal failure indicated by an elevated creatinine level. This is likely pre-renal due to hypovolemia or hepatorenal syndrome. Albumin infusion has improved the creatinine level, suggesting against hepatorenal syndrome.

Thrombocytopenia is also present, likely secondary to liver failure and splenomeg

   - Will treat supportively with blood products. Goal Hct is 21 if
   stable, will titrate transfusions if responding appropriately to blood.
   Will also treat with aggressive FFP transfusions to curtail bleeding.
   - Appreciate liver recs; EGD if evidence of brisk GIB
   - F/U peritoneal amylase level for pancreatitis /intestinal
   perforation.
   - Will re-discuss with surgery as patient continues to bleed despite
   aggressive medical tx x 3days.
   .
   # Cirrhosis / hyperbilirubinemia / [**Month/Year (2) 4182**] [**Month/Year (2) 4244**] thrombosis. Patient w/
   mild transaminitis (stable) with stable thrombocytopenia, ascites, LE
   edema, hepatosplenomegaly, and elevated INR.  This is likely secondary
   to cirrhosis from alcoholism with embarrassment by chronic
   acetaminophen use.  Currently not drinking for 1 month per patient and
   husband. [**Name (NI) **] [**Name2 (NI) 4244**] thrombosis seems acute due to no collateral flow
   in the [**Name2 (NI) 4182**] circulation on CT. EGD deferred by GI (feels anemia more
   likely due to hemolysis)
   - Follow liver enzymes
 bilirubin stable to decreasing
   - minimize non-essential meds
   - appreciate liver recs: continue lactulose, rifaximin, octreotide and
   midodrine. Pt completed 2 days of albumin infusion and steroids were
   stopped per hepatology.
   .
   # Acute renal failure. Cr trended up from 0.8 to peak of 3.0. FENa <1%,
   thus pre-renal due to hypovolemia (large stool output) or hepatorenal
   syndrome. Cr improved after albumin infusion, which argues against
   HRS.
   - Trend Cr
   - Renally dose meds.
   - Holding albumin per hepatology.
   .
   #  Thrombocytopenia. Improving. Likely secondary to liver failure and
   splenomegaly.  Evaluation for TTP and DIC will be difficult to
   interpret with liver failure.  Rare schistocytes on smear with elevated
   PTT, low fibrinogen, and direct hyperbilirubinemia.  However, LDH
   normal, arguing against TMA. E. coli O175:H7 neg argues against
   TTP/HUS. Received 1U platelets overnight.
   - Follow plt count and transfuse if plt < 10 or as needed to control
   abdominal bleeding
   .
   # Hypernatremia after initial hyponatremia: Initial hypoNa likely
   secondary to ascites and LE edema. Suspect pt became hyperNa due to TF.
   - Mix meds in D5W
   - Increase free water flushes to 300cc Q4hrs.
   - Recheck Na this afternoon and consider starting D5W if Na not fully
   corrected by then.
   .
   #.  LE edema.  Stable. B/l LE pitting edema almost certainly related to
   liver failure, as TTE did not show definitive etiology.
   #.  H/o alcohol abuse. Completed 5 days of high dose thiamine.
   - continue multivitamins, folate
   - SW consult when mental status improves
   .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, TF per nutrition recs, ISS
   .
   Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots (no HSQ given elevated INR and
   thrombocytopenia).
   .
   Access: PIV, PICC (placed [**3-19**])
   .
   Code: DNR/DNI
   .

   .

The patient is a 44-year-old female with a history of cirrhosis, presumed secondary to alcoholism and acetaminophen use. She is currently experiencing anemia, jaundice, and altered mental status. The patient has been diagnosed with several medical conditions including hepatic encephalopathy, spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), anemia, acute renal failure, thrombocytopenia, hypernatremia, and lower extremity (LE) edema. The patient's liver failure is likely due to a combination of alcohol abuse and chronic acetaminophen use.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hepatic Encephalopathy: The patient's altered mental status is consistent with hepatic encephalopathy, which is a complication of liver failure. This condition can lead to confusion, disorientation, and even coma if not properly managed.
2. Spontaneous Bacterial Peritonitis (SBP): The patient has developed SBP, a bacterial infection of the ascitic fluid in the abdomen. This condition can be life-threatening if not promptly treated with antibiotics.
3. Anemia: The patient has anemia, likely caused by multiple factors such as chronic disease, gastrointestinal bleeding, and intraperitoneal bleeding. Further evaluation is needed to determine the exact cause and appropriate management.
4. Acute Renal Failure: The patient has acute renal failure, characterized by a significant increase in creatinine levels. This may

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 65-year-old male with a history of cirrhosis, alcoholic hepatitis, and anemia, admitted to the ICU for acute liver failure. The patient's condition has been deteriorating rapidly, with significant hemodynamic instability and multiorgan dysfunction.

Over the past 24 hours, the patient's hemoglobin level has continued to fall despite aggressive transfusion of blood products. The patient has also experienced episodes of ventricular tachycardia, which were thought to be related to the positioning of the peripheral intravenous catheter (PICC) line. The line was pulled back, but the patient subsequently experienced another episode of ventricular tachycardia followed by sinus tachycardia.

The patient's potassium level was repleted, and a family meeting was held to discuss the continuation of do-not-resuscitate/do-not-intubate (DNR/DNI) status and ongoing transfusions. The patient's husband is not yet ready to proceed with these decisions.

Physical examination findings include anisocoria, diaphoresis, scleral icterus, clear lung fields, regular heart rhythm with a systolic murmur, tense abdomen with ascites, and bilateral lower extremity pitting edema. Neurological examination reveals alertness with minimal speech and eye tracking.

Laboratory results show worsening anemia, electrolyte imbalances, and elevated liver enzymes. Notably, the patient's hemoglobin level has decreased from 25.5 g/dL to 20.0 g/dL, and the hematocrit has decreased from 25.2% to 20.0%. The white blood cell count has fluctuated between 10.4 and 11.9 thousand cells/mm3. Platelet count has varied between 53 and 64 thousand cells/mm3. Renal function tests reveal elevated creatinine levels, indicating potential renal impairment.

The patient's condition is complicated by several medical issues, including acute anemia secondary to blood loss, electrolyte and fluid disorder, hepatorenal syndrome, and impaired skin integrity. The patient's history of cirrhosis, alcoholic hepatitis, and hemolytic anemia contributes to the complexity of the case.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Acute Anemia: The patient's ongoing blood loss and the inability to maintain hemoglobin levels may lead to further anemia, compromising tissue oxygenation and potentially causing organ dysfunction.

2. Electrolyte and Fluid Disorder: The patient's electrolyte imbalances, including low potassium and sodium levels, require careful management to prevent cardiac arrhythmias and other complications.

3. Hepatorenal Syndrome: The patient's liver failure and renal dysfunction increase the risk of developing hepatorenal syndrome, a potentially reversible form of kidney failure in patients with advanced liver disease.

4. Impaired Skin Integrity: The patient's tense abdomen with ascites and lower extremity edema suggest impaired skin integrity, which increases the risk of pressure ul

The patient has been receiving aggressive transfusion of blood products and is currently on mechanical ventilation.

1. Infection: Due to the patient's impaired immune system and prolonged hospital stay, there is a high risk of developing infections such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), catheter-related bloodstream infection (CRBSI), or urinary tract infection (UTI).
2. Bleeding: The patient's acute anemia is secondary to blood loss, which could be due to ongoing bleeding from the gastrointestinal tract or other sources. There is a risk of further bleeding complications, especially considering the patient's coagulopathy.
3. Liver failure: The patient's history of cirrhosis and alcoholic liver disease puts him at risk for further deterioration in liver function. This can lead to complications such as hepatic encephalopathy, coagulopathy, and hepatorenal syndrome.
4. Renal failure: The patient is already experiencing hepatorenal syndrome, which indicates compromised renal function. There is a risk of further deterioration in renal function, leading to acute kidney injury (AKI) or end-stage renal disease (ESRD).

   44 yo female with history of cirrhosis and now with decompensated liver
   failure and with encephalopathy that has improved with supportive Rx.
   She had transient worsening of renal failure which has shown some
   improvement in the setting of increased volume and support for
   component of HRS.  She has had persistence of anemia and medical Rx
   only available given signficant risk for surgery.  Last night and
   across yesterday she has evolved an increasing frequency of wide
   complex tachycardia which have been self limited but with duration of
   up to 35 beats.
   1) ANEMIA, ACUTE, SECONDARY TO BLOOD LOSS (HEMORRHAGE,
   BLEEDING)--Clearly most likely source is intraperitoneal.  Surgery
   consulted and aid from Hepatology team obtained
   -FFP to work to normalize INR
   -PRBC as needed for trend down
   -Will continue to look for alternative sources

   Encephaoloapthy-Lactulose, Rifaxamin
   SBP-Vanco/ZOsyn started
   Hepato-Renal Syndrome-Support with Octreotide/Midodrine

The patient is a 44-year-old female with a history of cirrhosis and decompensated liver failure, currently admitted to the ICU. She has been experiencing encephalopathy, anemia secondary to blood loss, renal failure, and an increasing frequency of wide complex tachycardia. The patient has received supportive care, including FFP and PRBC transfusions, lactulose, rifaximin, vancomycin, and piperacillin/tazobactam. The plan is to continue monitoring and treating the patient's acute issues, including blood loss anemia and arrhythmia. The patient's prognosis remains uncertain, and discussions have been held with the family regarding the possibility of hospice support if there is no significant recovery of hepatic function.

2. CIRRHOSIS: The patient's underlying cirrhosis is a chronic condition that contributes to liver dysfunction and portal hypertension. Complications such as ascites, hepatic encephalopathy, and hepatorenal syndrome may arise if not properly managed.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 44-year-old female with a history of cirrhosis secondary to alcoholism and acetaminophen use. She presents with anemia, jaundice, and altered mental status. The patient has multiple medical complications that can arise from her condition. These include:

1. Altered mental status: The patient is experiencing hepatic encephalopathy and spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). Treatment includes continuing lactulose and rifaximin, as well as treating hypernatremia.

2. SBP: The patient received Unasyn for SBP prophylaxis and was started on ceftriaxone upon arrival. The second tap showed increased white blood cells with a left shift, and the CTX was changed to Zosyn on 3/15.

3. Anemia: The patient has a baseline anemia of chronic disease, low-grade gastrointestinal bleeding, and evidence of intraperitoneal bleeding on paracentesis. She received 4 more units of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) on 3/19.

4. Hyperbilirubinemia: The patient has mild transaminitis with stable thrombocytopenia, ascites, lower extremity edema, hepatosplenomegaly, and elevated international normalized ratio (INR). This is likely secondary to cirrhosis from alcoholism with embarrassment by chronic acetaminophen use.

5. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine (Cr) trended up from 0.8 to a peak of 3.0, indicating acute renal failure. FENa (<1%) suggests pre-renal cause due to hypovolemia or hepatorenal syndrome (HRS). The Cr improved after albumin infusion, which argues against HRS.

6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is improving, likely secondary to liver failure and splenomegaly. Evaluation for thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is difficult to interpret with liver failure.

7. Hypernatremia: The patient initially had hyponatremia secondary to ascites and lower extremity edema, but then became hypernatremic. This is suspected to be due to total parenteral nutrition (TF).

8. Lower extremity edema: The patient has stable bilateral lower extremity pitting edema, which is likely related to liver failure.

9. History of alcohol abuse: The patient completed 5 days of high-dose thiamine.

10. Other issues: The patient's code status is DNR/DNI, and she has a PICC line, 20-gauge and 18-gauge lines, and is receiving renal nutrition.

The patient is a male with a history of cirrhosis of the liver, alcoholic anemia, and hemolytic anemia. They have been admitted to the ICU with multiple medical complications. The patient's code status has been changed to "Full," indicating that they wish to receive all possible measures to prolong life.

The patient received fresh frozen plasma (FFP) through the morning of [**3-23**] and then okayed to stop. Transplant [**Doctor First Name 3**] recommended Factor VII. As the patient's hematocrit (Hct) stabilized, they opted to continue with FFP for now.

A speech/swallow evaluation has been ordered as the patient is asking for fluids. Bladder pressure remains high at 21 in the morning and 22 in the afternoon. Peritoneal amylase is within normal limits, and urine culture shows yeast >100K, leading to a Foley change.

The patient has no known drug allergies. They have received vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam in the past.

Infusions include pantoprazole (Protonix) started on [**2174-3-22**] at 08:30 AM. Other medications are also being administered.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 44 year old female with cirrhosis presumed secondary to
   alcoholism and acetaminophen use, here with anemia, jaundice, and
   altered mental status. Has increasing O2 requirement today and
   abdomenal exam not fully consistent with simple ascites.
   .
   # Hypoxia: Likely multifactorial. Has been receiving increasing doses
   of morphine for abdominal pain, which could contribute to decreased
   respiratory drive. Decreased chest wall compliance due to large
   ascites. Volume overload (LOS 18 L positive) as has been receiving
   large amounts of blood products.
   - CXR to assess for pulm edema/PNA/other processes
   - Check ABG
   - onsider Lasix if + pulm edema due to volume overload
   - Keep O2 sat >92%
   - minimize sedating medications
   .
   # Abnormal abdominal exam. Noted to be tympanic on percussion centrally
   despite large ascites. Also tense and distended in upper quadrants but
   relaxed and soft in the lower quadrants. Unable to check residuals with
   her dobhoff. Peritoneal amylase =13, thus unlikely pancreatitis or
   intestinal perf.
   - Check KUB for ileus/obstruction
   - Minimize opiate use
   - Check C. diff
   # Altered mental status. Waxing and [**Doctor Last Name 282**]. Likely hepatic
   encephalopathy and SBP. Initially was hyponatremic on presentation, now
   persistently hypernatremic.  Head CT on [**3-13**] neg for acute intracranial
   process. Consider repeat head CT if suspect cerebral edema in setting
   of fulminant liver failure
   - Continue lactulose and rifaxamin (currently stooling well)
   - Treat hypernatremia as below
   .
   # SBP: Received Unasyn x 3 days at OSH for SBP Prophylaxis. Started
   Ceftriaxone upon arrival here. S/P diagnostic paracentesis - Second tap
   showed incr WBC with L shift, changed CTX to Zosyn on [**3-15**], per
   informal ID recs.  Bladder pressure elevated on morning of [**3-20**], pt
   increasingly uncomfortable and dyspneic.  Therapeutic para done [**3-20**] to
   remove 2.5L grossly bloody fluid. Requiring increasing amounts of pain
   meds.
   - D/C zosyn (Day 1=[**3-15**]) and Vanco (Day 1 =[**3-17**]) today and start Cipro
   for total [**Month/Year (2) 114**] course of 2 weeks (count day 1 of zosyn as day 1 of [**Month/Year (2) 114**]
   course, thus [**3-15**]) per liver recs. Once completes 2 weeks of [**Last Name (LF) 114**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**]
   continue cipro at prophylactic dosage
   - peritoneal fluid showing no growth on culture
   .
   # Anemia: Has been stable x 24 hours with aggressive FFP transfusions.
   Cause of anemia likely multifactorial, biggest contributor being
   intrabdominal bleeding after paracenteses superimposed on baseline
   anemia of chronic disease. Also has low grade GI bleed (guaiac pos, not
   grossly bloody). Unlikely that the patient has DIC/hemolysis, since lab
   data underwhelming - low retic index, direct bilirubinemia, normal LDH,
   normal haptoglobin.
   - Will hold off on further FFP transfusions as Hct stable for the time
   being
   - [**Hospital1 **] hct check
   - Will treat supportively with blood products. Goal Hct is 21 if
   stable, will titrate transfusions if responding appropriately to blood.
   - Appreciate liver recs
   - GSurgery/ transplant surgery recs: no OR
   .
   # Cirrhosis / hyperbilirubinemia / [**Hospital1 4182**] [**Hospital1 4244**] thrombosis. Patient w/
   mild transaminitis (stable) with stable thrombocytopenia, ascites, LE
   edema, hepatosplenomegaly, and elevated INR.  This is likely secondary
   to cirrhosis from alcoholism with embarrassment by chronic
   acetaminophen use.  Currently not drinking for 1 month per patient and
   husband. [**Name (NI) **] [**Name2 (NI) 4244**] thrombosis seems acute due to no collateral flow
   in the [**Name2 (NI) 4182**] circulation on CT. EGD deferred by GI (feels anemia more
   likely due to hemolysis)
   - Follow liver enzymes
 bilirubin stable in upper 40s
   - minimize non-essential meds
   - appreciate liver recs: will stop octreotide and midodrine today.
   .
   # Acute renal failure. Now resolved. Cr trended up to peak of 3.0
   previously. FENa <1%, thus pre-renal due to hypovolemia (large stool
   output) or hepatorenal syndrome. Cr improved after albumin infusion
   (x3), which argues against HRS.
   - Trend Cr
   - Renally dose meds.
   .
   #  Thrombocytopenia. Improved. Likely secondary to liver failure and
   splenomegaly.  Evaluation for TTP and DIC will be difficult to
   interpret with liver failure.  Rare schistocytes on smear with elevated
   PTT, low fibrinogen, and direct hyperbilirubinemia.  However, LDH
   normal, arguing against TMA. E. coli O175:H7 neg argues against
   TTP/HUS.
   - Follow plt count and transfuse if plt < 10 or as needed to control
   abdominal bleeding
   .
   # Hypernatremia after initial hyponatremia: Initial hypoNa likely
   secondary to ascites and LE edema. Suspect pt became hyperNa due to TF.
   - Mix meds in D5W
   - Cont free water flushes to 300cc Q4hrs.
   - Cont D5W at 75cc/hr (was decreased to 35cc/hr overnight, will turn it
   back up)
   .
   #.  H/o alcohol abuse. Completed 5 days of high dose thiamine.
   - continue multivitamins, folate
   - SW consult when mental status improves
   .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, TF per nutrition recs, ISS
   .
   Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots (no HSQ given elevated INR and
   thrombocytopenia).
   .
   Access: PIV, PICC (placed [**3-19**])
   .
   Code: Full code
   .
   Communication: Patient, Husband [**Name (NI) 117**]
   Health [**Name (NI) 232**] Proxy [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) **] [**Name (NI) 4794**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 4795**] (h), [**Telephone/Fax (1) 4796**] (w)
   .
   Disposition: ICU for now while requiring face mask for hypoxia. Once
   resp status improves, will transfer to floor

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 44-year-old female with cirrhosis secondary to alcoholism and acetaminophen use. She presents with anemia, jaundice, and altered mental status. She is currently in the ICU with multiple medical complications, including hypoxia, abnormal abdominal exam, altered mental status, anemia, and acute renal failure.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxia: The patient is experiencing increasing oxygen requirements, which could be due to decreased respiratory drive from morphine use, decreased chest wall compliance due to large ascites, or volume overload. A chest X-ray should be ordered to assess for pulmonary edema, pneumonia, or other processes. ABG should be checked, and lasix may be considered if there is pulmonary edema due to volume overload. The goal is to maintain O2 saturation above 92%.

2. Abnormal Abdominal Exam: The patient's abdominal exam shows tympanic percussion centrally despite large ascites, suggesting the presence of an intra-abdominal collection. Peritoneal amylase levels are normal, making pancreatitis or intestinal perforation less likely. Further evaluation is needed, including checking for ileus or obstruction in the kidneys, ureters, and bladder. Minimizing opiate use may also be helpful.

3. Altered Mental Status: The patient is exhibiting signs of hepatic encephalopathy and suspected spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). A head CT should be repeated if cerebral

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 44-year-old female with cirrhosis and hepatic failure. She has continued failure of hepatic function but shows improved stability in renal function, mental status, and intra-peritoneal bleeding. The patient's anemia is secondary to blood loss, and she has not received a transfusion in over 24 hours. Her hemoglobin concentration (HCT) is unchanged.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Anemia-Secondary to blood loss: The patient's anemia is a result of ongoing blood loss, which can lead to decreased oxygen-carrying capacity and tissue hypoxia. If not managed appropriately, this can result in further deterioration of the patient's condition.

2. Cirrhosis/Ascites/SBP: The patient has cirrhosis with associated complications such as ascites and suspected spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). If left untreated, SBP can progress to sepsis and multiorgan failure.

3. EtOH abuse: The patient has a history of ethanol abuse, which contributes to the development and progression of cirrhosis. Continued alcohol consumption can exacerbate liver damage and lead to further complications.

4. Acute Renal Failure: The patient has acute renal failure, characterized by oliguria and elevated serum creatinine levels. Without proper management, renal failure can progress to end-stage renal disease, necessitating dialysis or kidney transplantation.

5. Hypoxemia: The patient is experiencing hypoxemia

Summary:
The patient is a 44-year-old female with a history of presumed secondary cirrhosis due to alcoholism and acetaminophen use. She is currently experiencing hypoxia, severe ascites without obstruction, anemia, jaundice, and altered mental status. The patient has been diagnosed with multifocal pneumonia, urinary tract infection, and hepatic encephalopathy. She also has a history of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) and has undergone therapeutic paracentesis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxia: The patient's hypoxia is likely due to decreased respiratory drive caused by morphine. The improvement in hypoxia after Narcan administration suggests opioid-induced respiratory depression. Close monitoring of oxygen saturation and avoidance of narcotics are recommended.

2. Multifocal Pneumonia: The patient's new opacities on chest X-ray suggest multifocal pneumonia. Antibiotic therapy should be initiated, and follow-up chest X-rays should be performed to monitor the progression of the infection.

3. Urinary Tract Infection (UTI): The patient has a positive urinalysis, indicating a UTI. She is already on ciprofloxacin, and further follow-up on urine culture is necessary. Adjustments to antibiotic therapy may be required based on the culture results.

4. Hepatic Encephalopathy: The patient exhibits signs of hepatic encephalopathy, including altered mental status. Treatment should involve continuing lactul

Summary: The patient is a 44-year-old female with cirrhosis, presumed secondary to alcoholism and acetaminophen use, presenting with anemia, jaundice, and altered mental status. She has been admitted to the ICU for hypoxia, likely due to decreased respiratory drive caused by morphine. The patient also has severe ascites without evidence of obstruction, tense and distended abdomen in the upper quadrants, and clear lungs bilaterally. She is experiencing a urinary tract infection, as indicated by a positive urinalysis and culture pending. The patient has been receiving antibiotics for suspected spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) prophylaxis and treatment. Her liver enzymes are elevated, and she has evidence of portal hypertension with splenomegaly and esophageal varices. She has thrombocytopenia likely secondary to liver failure and splenomegaly. The patient has a history of alcohol abuse and completed 5 days of high-dose thiamine. She is currently being treated for multifocal pneumonia, and her respiratory support has been adjusted accordingly.

Summary:
The patient is a 44-year-old female with a history of cirrhosis, presumed secondary to alcoholism and acetaminophen use. She presents with anemia, jaundice, and altered mental status. The patient's condition has been complicated by several medical complications, including hypoxia, abnormal abdominal exam findings suggestive of ascites, urinary tract infection, hepatic encephalopathy, spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), anemia, acute renal failure, thrombocytopenia, hypernatremia, and possible hepatocellular carcinoma. 

The patient's hypoxia improved after receiving Narcan and decreased ascites visible on ultrasound. She was given Lasix to address fluid overload but had little increase in urine output. The patient is currently on Cipro to complete a total of 2-week antibiotic course.

Her abdominal exam shows tense ascites in the upper half of the abdomen with decreased bowel sounds. The patient is unable to answer questions regarding pain due to moaning at baseline. 

The patient's lab results indicate elevated liver enzymes, low platelet count, and abnormal kidney function tests. Her blood cultures are pending, and imaging studies reveal severe ascites without evidence of obstruction and new multiple opacities in both lungs suggestive of multifocal pneumonia.

The patient's altered mental status is likely due to hepatic encephalopathy and SBP. She has been treated with lactulose and rifaximin.

Summary:
The patient is a 43-year-old male with a history of cirrhosis and alcohol abuse, presenting to the ICU with severe ascites, acute kidney injury, and hypoxemia. He has been on mechanical ventilation and receiving intravenous fluids. The patient's vital signs are stable, but he is experiencing acute pain, hypernatremia, coagulopathy, anemia secondary to blood loss, electrolyte and fluid disorder, hepatorenal syndrome, impaired skin integrity, and a history of hemolytic anemia.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hepatorenal Syndrome: This is a type of kidney failure that can occur in patients with advanced liver disease, such as cirrhosis. It is characterized by low urine output and elevated blood creatinine levels.
2. Hypoxemia: The patient's low oxygen saturation (SpO2) indicates impaired gas exchange, which may be due to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) or pneumonia. This can lead to further respiratory complications if not managed properly.
3. Coagulopathy: The patient's prolonged prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), along with low fibrinogen levels, suggest a bleeding tendency. This increases the risk of bleeding complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or intracranial hemorrhage.
4. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's elevated serum creatinine and decreased urine output indicate AKI, which

1. Hypoxia: The patient's oxygen requirements have improved slightly since yesterday, but she is still not back to baseline. Summary:
The patient is a 44-year-old female with a history of cirrhosis, presumed secondary to alcoholism and acetaminophen use. She presents with anemia, jaundice, and altered mental status. The patient has severe ascites, no evidence of obstruction, and new opacities on chest X-ray suggestive of multifocal pneumonia in progress. She also has thrombocytopenia, elevated INR, hepatosplenomegaly, and mild transaminitis. 

The patient's current condition includes hypoxia likely due to decreased respiratory drive from morphine as well as possible new multifocal pneumonia. She has acute renal failure with a creatinine level of 1.5, likely secondary to hypovolemia or hepatorenal syndrome. The patient's altered mental status is likely hepatic encephalopathy and spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). 

The patient's medical history includes alcohol abuse and chronic acetaminophen use. She has been treated with various antibiotics, including cefepime and vancomycin, but her recent urine culture showed growth of E. coli O157:H7, which argues against TTP/HUS. 

The patient's current plan includes weaning off supplemental oxygen, avoiding narcotics, and monitoring for any changes in her condition. She is to receive albumin infusions and continue lactulose and rifaximin for hepatic encephalopathy. The patient will continue with ciprof

- The patient is a 44-year-old female with a history of cirrhosis secondary to alcoholism and acetaminophen use.
- She presents with anemia, jaundice, and altered mental status.
- The patient has increased oxygen requirements and is at risk for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP).
- She also has acute renal failure with a rising creatinine level, likely due to hypovolemia or hepatorenal syndrome.
- The patient has suspected spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) and was treated with antibiotics.
- She has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding, both gross and microscopic.
- The patient's thrombocytopenia is likely secondary to liver failure and splenomegaly.
- She has hypernatremia and was previously hyponatremic.
- The patient's altered mental status is likely due to hepatic encephalopathy and SBP.
- She is on prophylactic antibiotics and has a Foley catheter in place.
- The patient's condition is stable, and she is being closely monitored.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxia: The patient's hypoxia may be due to multifocal pneumonia and decreased respiratory drive caused by morphine. It is important to monitor her oxygen saturation levels and consider weaning off supplemental oxygen as tolerated.
2. Acute renal failure: The patient's renal function is compromised, and her creatinine level is elevated. Further evaluation is

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 44-year-old female with a history of cirrhosis, presumed secondary to alcoholism and acetaminophen use. She is currently experiencing hypoxia, likely due to decreased respiratory drive from morphine use as well as possible new multifocal pneumonia. The patient also has severe ascites without evidence of obstruction, tense and distended abdomen in the upper quadrants, and an altered mental status. She is anemic, jaundiced, and has evidence of gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient's blood cultures are pending, and she is already on ciprofloxacin for suspected urinary tract infection. She has received Unasyn prophylaxis for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) and has been treated with various antibiotics for her condition. Her renal function has improved after albumin infusion but remains abnormal, and she has stable thrombocytopenia. The patient has hypernatremia and requires further evaluation for potential causes. The patient is a 43-year-old male with a history of cirrhosis of the liver, alcoholic hepatitis, and anemia, who was admitted to the ICU for suspected septic shock. On admission, the patient had severe ascites and multiple new opacities on the chest X-ray, suggesting multifocal pneumonia. The initial treatment included paracentesis, lasix for fluid overload, and broad-spectrum antibiotics. However, the patient's condition worsened, and there was no improvement in ascites despite the medical interventions. The patient's blood pressure and heart rate remained stable, but the respiratory rate increased, and oxygen saturation decreased to 94%. The patient received naloxone for hypoxia and showed improvement with decreased ascites visible on ultrasound.

The patient has a history of alcohol abuse and cirrhosis of the liver. He presented with severe ascites, which is an accumulation of fluid in the abdomen commonly seen in cirrhosis. The ascites did not respond to medical management, and the patient's overall condition deteriorated. The presence of new opacities on the chest X-ray indicates possible pneumonia, which can be a serious complication in patients with cirrhosis due to their weakened immune system.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 44-year-old female with a history of cirrhosis, presenting with hepatic failure, hypoxemia, and altered mental status. She has experienced worsening renal function and intra-peritoneal bleeding. The patient is currently in the ICU and is receiving various treatments for her conditions.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hepatic Failure: The patient's hepatic failure can lead to complications such as hepatic encephalopathy, coagulopathy, hepatorenal syndrome, and hepatopulmonary syndrome.
2. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status may be a result of hepatic encephalopathy. If not properly managed, it can progress to deep coma or death.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure requires careful monitoring and management. Complications may include fluid overload, electrolyte imbalances, and the need for dialysis.
4. Intra-peritoneal Bleeding: If not managed appropriately, the intra-peritoneal bleeding can worsen, leading to hemodynamic instability and potential shock.
5. Hypoxemia: The patient's hypoxemia needs to be addressed promptly to prevent further respiratory compromise. Possible complications include pneumonia and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
6. Infection: Due to the patient's compromised immune system, there is a risk of developing infections such as spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), sepsis, and multi-organ dysfunction syndrome.

She has ongoing issues of altered mental status, renal failure, and coagulopathy with blood loss anemia.

The potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Altered Mental Status: The patient has an altered mental status, which can be attributed to hepatic encephalopathy. This condition needs to be managed with medications such as rifaximin and lactulose. Additionally, minimizing sedating medications is important. There is a concern for new pneumonia due to the presence of a right-sided infiltrate, although fevers and coughs are not prominent.

2. Hepato-Renal Syndrome/Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels are worsening, indicating potential renal failure. Management with medications like midodrine, octreotide, and albumin should continue to support kidney function.

3. Coagulopathy: The patient has a coagulopathy with a flank hematoma noted on the left side. This could be due to blood loss, leading to a drop in hemoglobin concentration. Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) should be given as needed for acute bleeding episodes.

4. Pneumonia: The presence of a right-sided infiltrate raises concerns about pneumonia. The patient's current antibiotic regimen should be adjusted accordingly.

 aspiration vs edema

   coverage as well.

She has multiple complications including altered mental status, acute respiratory failure, hepato-renal syndrome/acute renal failure, and coagulopathy. The patient was unable to stay on the medical floor due to worsening mental status and tachypnea, and was returned to the ICU for further care.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Altered Mental Status: The patient is experiencing altered mental status, which can be attributed to several factors including renal failure, pneumonia, and underlying cirrhosis. It is essential to minimize sedating medications and consider potential causes for the altered mental status.
2. Acute Respiratory Failure: The patient is showing signs of acute respiratory failure, possibly due to new pneumonia. The presence of a right-sided infiltrate on imaging suggests a pulmonary infection. Intubation may be necessary, and ongoing monitoring of ABG (arterial blood gas) values is important.
3. Hepato-Renal Syndrome/Acute Renal Failure: The patient's serum creatinine levels are worsening, indicating possible hepato-renal syndrome or acute renal failure. Close monitoring of bladder pressure is crucial, and treatment with midodrine, octreotide, and albumin should continue.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient has evidence of coagulopathy, as indicated by a flank hemat

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 44 year old female with cirrhosis presumed secondary to
   alcohol abuse and tylenol overuse who is status post a 2 week stay in
   the MICU and is transferred back with worsening renal function, mental
   status and respiratory distress.
   .
   # Hypoxia: CXR with possible multifocal pna, but has had decreased
   oxygen requirement since narcan. She also completed 9 days of
   vanc/zosyn for SBP thus it would be unlikely that pt developed a new
   PNA. However, VRE, fungal or other ESBL organism is a possibility. Her
   abdominal girth may also be contributing to decreased chest wall
   compliance. Worsening hypoxia overnight [**3-25**], becoming more somnolent,
   able to maintain O2 sats > 90% with 100 FiO2. Improved somewhat with
   Narcan. Satting in mid-90s on 4-5L O2 NC this morning.
   - CXR shows new infiltrate
 aspiration vs edema; will treat with
   Vanc/Zosyn again as this was a new event/infiltrate. Consider VRE
   coverage as well.
   - Will try to avoid intubation as it will likely be very difficult to
   extubated; however OK to intubate if necessary per family.
   - Avoid narcotics (none given since [**3-24**])
   - Repeat bladder pressure (15 this morning)
   - Wean supplemental O2 as tolerated for goal O2 sat >92%
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Cr trended up to peak of 3.0 previously. FENa
   <1%, thus pre-renal due to hypovolemia (large stool output) or
   hepatorenal syndrome. Cr improved after albumin infusion (x3), which
   argued against HRS.  Cr had normalized x 5 days but again elevated on
   [**3-23**] and is increasing.  HRS treatment was discontinued and has been
   restarted over the last several days.
   - Continue albumin for likely intravascular volume depletion and HRS
   - Continue octreotide , increase midodrine per Liver
   - Follow [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   - Renally dose meds
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # Altered mental status. Waxing and [**Doctor Last Name 282**]. Likely hepatic
   encephalopathy and SBP. Also persistently hypernatremic which is likely
   contributing to her AMS.  Has been receiving free water and Na is
   stable and mildly elevated.  Head CT on [**3-13**] neg for acute intracranial
   process.  Appears a bit more altered this morning, but is still
   responsive to voice.
   - Continue lactulose and rifaxamin (stooling well)
   - Treat hypernatremia as below
   .
   # SBP: Received Unasyn x 3 days at OSH for SBP Prophylaxis. Started
   Ceftriaxone upon arrival here. S/P diagnostic paracentesis - Second tap
   showed incr WBC with L shift, changed CTX to Zosyn on [**3-15**], per
   informal ID recs.  Vanc/Zosyn d/c
d [**3-23**] and Cipro started to complete
   total 2 week abd course. No growth on culture of peritoneal fluid.
   Bladder pressure elevated on morning of [**3-20**], pt increasingly
   uncomfortable and dyspneic. Therapeutic para done [**3-20**] to remove 2.5L
   grossly bloody fluid. Required increasing pain meds [**Date range (1) 5037**] but d/c
   [**3-23**] because no longer complaining of pain.
   - Restarted vanc/Zosyn, but will switch to Cipro after PNA resolves
   - Recheck bladder pressure today with goal < 20mmHg
   .
   # Anemia: Stable after aggressive FFP transfusions. Cause likely
   multifactorial, biggest contributor being intrabdominal bleeding after
   paracenteses, superimposed on baseline anemia of chronic disease. Also
   has low grade GI bleed (guaiac pos, not grossly bloody). Unlikely that
   the patient has DIC/hemolysis, since lab data underwhelming - low retic
   index, direct bilirubinemia, normal LDH, normal haptoglobin. GSurgery/
   transplant surgery recs: no OR.
   - Will hold off on further FFP transfusions for now
   - Daily HCT check
   - Will treat supportively with blood products. Goal Hct is 21 if
   stable, will titrate transfusions if responding appropriately to blood.
   .
   # Cirrhosis / hyperbilirubinemia / portal vein thrombosis: Patient w/
   mild transaminitis (stable) with stable thrombocytopenia, ascites, LE
   edema, hepatosplenomegaly, and elevated INR.  This is likely secondary
   to cirrhosis from alcoholism with exacerbation from chronic
   acetaminophen use.  Currently not drinking for 1 month per patient and
   husband prior to admission . Portal vein thrombosis seems acute due to
   no collateral flow in the portal circulation on CT. EGD deferred by GI
   (feels anemia more likely due to hemolysis). D/c
d midodrine/octreotide
   3/25 per liver.
   - Follow liver enzymes
 bilirubin stable and elevated
   - Continue midodrine/octreotide as above
   - minimize non-essential meds
   - Appreciate liver recs, will continue to have ongoing discussion with
   liver team regarding prognosis and likelihood of recovery.
   .
   # UTI: Positive U/A on [**3-23**], culture growing yeast. On ciprofloxacin.
   Foley changed overnight [**Date range (1) 5037**]. Will follow up on culture and adjust
   abx as needed.  Repeat culture growing yeast.
   - Continue cipro
   - Consider antifungal treatment if patient continues to decompensate,
   though no positive blood cultures
   .
   #  Thrombocytopenia. Improved. Likely secondary to liver failure and
   splenomegaly.  Evaluation for TTP and DIC difficult to interpret with
   liver failure.  Rare schistocytes on smear with elevated PTT, low
   fibrinogen, and direct hyperbilirubinemia.  However, LDH normal,
   arguing against TMA. E. coli O175:H7 neg argues against TTP/HUS.
   - Follow plt count and transfuse if plt < 10 or as needed to control
   bleeding
   .
   # Hypernatremia after initial hyponatremia: Initial hypoNa likely
   secondary to ascites and LE edema. Suspect pt became hyperNa due to TF.
   - [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   - Mix meds in D5W
   - Cont free water flushes to 300cc Q4hrs

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 44 year old female with cirrhosis presumed secondary to
   alcohol abuse and tylenol overuse who is status post a 2 week stay in
   the MICU and is transferred back with worsening renal function, mental
   status and respiratory distress.
   .
   # Hypoxia: CXR with possible multifocal pna, but has had decreased
   oxygen requirement since narcan. She also completed 9 days of
   vanc/zosyn for SBP thus it would be unlikely that pt developed a new
   PNA. However, VRE, fungal or other ESBL organism is a possibility. Her
   abdominal girth may also be contributing to decreased chest wall
   compliance. Worsening hypoxia overnight [**3-25**], becoming more somnolent,
   able to maintain O2 sats > 90% with 100 FiO2. Improved somewhat with
   Narcan. Satting in mid-90s on 4-5L O2 NC this morning.
   - CXR shows new infiltrate
 aspiration vs edema; will treat with
   Vanc/Zosyn again as this was a new event/infiltrate. Consider VRE
   coverage as well.
   - Will try to avoid intubation as it will likely be very difficult to
   extubated; however OK to intubate if necessary per family.
   - Avoid narcotics (none given since [**3-24**])
   - Repeat bladder pressure (15 this morning)
   - Wean supplemental O2 as tolerated for goal O2 sat >92%
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Cr trended up to peak of 3.0 previously. FENa
   <1%, thus pre-renal due to hypovolemia (large stool output) or
   hepatorenal syndrome. Cr improves after albumin infusion (5 infusions
   of 75g each so far), which argues against HRS. HRS treatment was
   discontinued and has been restarted over the last several days.
   - Continue octreotide, midodrine per Liver
   - Follow [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   - Renally dose meds
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # Altered mental status. Waxing and [**Doctor Last Name 282**]. Likely hepatic
   encephalopathy and SBP. Also persistently hypernatremic which is likely
   contributing to her AMS.  Has been receiving free water and Na is
   stable and mildly elevated.  Head CT on [**3-13**] neg for acute intracranial
   process.  Appears a bit more altered this morning, but is still
   responsive to voice.
   - Increase lactulose and continue rifaxamin; quantify stool output to
   monitor response
   - Treat hypernatremia as below
   .
   # SBP: Received Unasyn x 3 days at OSH for SBP Prophylaxis. Started
   Ceftriaxone upon arrival here. S/P diagnostic paracentesis - Second tap
   showed incr WBC with L shift, changed CTX to Zosyn on [**3-15**], per
   informal ID recs.  Also added Vanc. Vanc/Zosyn d/c
d [**3-23**] with
   intention of switching to Cipro, however given new infiltrate on CXR
   along with increasing resp distress Vanc and Zosyn were re-started. No
   growth on culture of peritoneal fluid. Therapeutic para done [**3-20**] to
   remove 2.5L grossly bloody fluid.
   - Continue Vanc/Zosyn for now, but will switch to Cipro after PNA
   resolves
   - Recheck bladder pressure
   .
   # Anemia: Stable after aggressive FFP transfusions. Cause likely
   multifactorial, biggest contributor being intrabdominal bleeding after
   paracenteses, superimposed on baseline anemia of chronic disease. Also
   has low grade GI bleed (guaiac pos, not grossly bloody). Unlikely that
   the patient has DIC/hemolysis, since lab data underwhelming - low retic
   index, direct bilirubinemia, normal LDH, normal haptoglobin. GSurgery/
   transplant surgery recs: no OR.
   - Will hold off on further FFP transfusions for now
   - Daily HCT check
   - Will treat supportively with blood products. Goal Hct is 21 if
   stable, will titrate transfusions if responding appropriately to blood.
   .
   # Cirrhosis / hyperbilirubinemia / portal vein thrombosis: Patient w/
   mild transaminitis (stable) with stable thrombocytopenia, ascites, LE
   edema, hepatosplenomegaly, and elevated INR.  This is likely secondary
   to cirrhosis from alcoholism with exacerbation from chronic
   acetaminophen use.  Currently not drinking for 1 month per patient and
   husband prior to admission . Portal vein thrombosis seems acute due to
   no collateral flow in the portal circulation on CT. EGD deferred by GI
   (feels anemia more likely due to hemolysis). D/c
d midodrine/octreotide
   3/25 per liver.
   - Follow liver enzymes
 bilirubin stable and elevated
   - Continue midodrine/octreotide as above
   - minimize non-essential meds
   - Appreciate liver recs, will continue to have ongoing discussion with
   liver team regarding prognosis and likelihood of recovery.
   .
   # UTI: Positive U/A on [**3-23**], culture growing yeast. Foley changed
   overnight [**Date range (1) 5037**].
   - Consider antifungal treatment if patient decompensates, though no
   positive blood cultures
   .
   #  Thrombocytopenia. Improved. Likely secondary to liver failure and
   splenomegaly.  Evaluation for TTP and DIC difficult to interpret with
   liver failure.  Rare schistocytes on smear with elevated PTT, low
   fibrinogen, and direct hyperbilirubinemia.  However, LDH normal,
   arguing against TMA. E. coli O175:H7 neg argues against TTP/HUS.
   - Follow plt count and transfuse if plt < 10 or as needed to control
   bleeding
   .
   # Hypernatremia after initial hyponatremia: Initial hypoNa likely
   secondary to ascites and LE edema. Suspect pt became hyperNa due to TF.
   - Mix meds in D5W
   - Cont free water flushes to 300cc Q4hrs
   - Continue D5W at 100cc/hr for now, recheck lytes in afternoon.
   .
   #.  H/o alcohol abuse. Completed 5 days of high dose thiamine.
   - continue multivitamins, folate
   - SW consult when mental status improves
   .
   # FEN: IVF as above, replete electrolytes, TF per nutrition recs, ISS
   .
   Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots (no HSQ given elevated INR and
   thrombocytopenia), PPI
   .
   Access: PIV, PICC (placed [**3-19**])
   .
   Code: Full code.  Ongoing discussion between liver team, MICU team and
   family given patient's declining status. Poor prognosis.
   .

Summary:
The patient is a 44-year-old female with a history of cirrhosis, likely secondary to alcohol abuse and Tylenol overuse. She has been admitted to the ICU multiple times and is currently experiencing worsening renal function, mental status changes, and respiratory distress. The patient's medical history includes alcohol abuse, acute renal failure, hepatic encephalopathy, spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), anemia, portal vein thrombosis, urinary tract infection (UTI), thrombocytopenia, hypernatremia, and hypoxia.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxia: The patient is experiencing worsening hypoxia, which may be due to multifocal pneumonia or aspiration. The patient's oxygen requirement has decreased since Narcan administration, but she still requires supplemental oxygen. A new infiltrate is noted on the chest X-ray, which could indicate a possible infection or edema. Intubation may be necessary if the patient's condition worsens.

2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels have been trending up, indicating worsening renal function. She has been treated with albumin infusions and hepatorenal syndrome (HRS) treatment. However, her renal function has normalized temporarily but has again become elevated. Continuing albumin infusions, octreotide, and midodrine may be beneficial. Avoiding nephrotoxins and following electrolyte levels are also important.

3. Altered Mental Status: The patient is likely experiencing hepatic encephalopathy and SBP. She is hypernatremic, which could be contributing to her altered mental status. Lactulose and rifaximin should be continued to manage hepatic encephalopathy. Treating hypernatremia and addressing potential causes such as SBP are crucial.

4. SBP: The patient has been diagnosed with SBP and has undergone a therapeutic paracentesis to remove grossly bloody fluid. She has been on ceftriaxone and has completed a two-week abdominal course of antibiotics. No growth was observed on the culture of peritoneal fluid. Rechecking bladder pressure and monitoring for signs of infection or worsening symptoms are essential.

5. Anemia: The patient has stable anemia likely due to intrabdominal bleeding after paracentesis, superimposed on baseline anemia of chronic disease. Low-grade GI bleeding has also been identified. It is important to monitor the patient's hemoglobin and hematocrit levels and transfuse as needed.

6. Cirrhosis/Hyperbilirubinemia/Portal Vein Thrombosis: The patient has cirrhosis secondary to alcoholism, with exacerbation from chronic acetaminophen use. She has stable thrombocytopenia, ascites, leg edema, hepatosplenomegaly, and elevated INR. Portal vein thrombosis seems acute, and it is important to follow liver

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 44 year old female with cirrhosis presumed secondary to
   alcohol abuse and tylenol overuse who is status post a 2 week stay in
   the MICU and is transferred back with worsening renal function, mental
   status and respiratory distress.
   .
   # Hypoxia: CXR with possible multifocal pna, but has had decreased
   oxygen requirement since narcan. She also has been on vanc/zosyn for
   the last 9 days so new HAP would be unlikely.  However, VRE, fungal or
   other ESBL organism is a possibility. No cough or fever for the last 24
   hours.  Currently appears tachypneic and uncomfortable. KUB yesterday
   also showed severe ascites, but patient's abdomen at this time appears
   to be predominantly distended from abdominal gas, likely a result of
   lactulose administration.  Bladder pressures have been relatively
   stable in the high teens.   Worsening hypoxia overnight [**3-25**], becoming
   more somnolent, able to maintain O2 sats > 90% with 100 FiO2. Improved
   somewhat with Narcan.
   - CXR shows new infiltrate
 aspiration vs edema
   - Likely needs to be intubated, but will monitor with ABG for worsening
   hypoxemia and hypercarbia
   - Avoid narcotics
   - Repeat bladder pressure
   - Wean supplemental O2 as tolerated for goal O2 sat >92%
   - Would be helpful to get sputum sample though patient is not likely to
   cooperate with this.  Will treat for multifocal pna with vanc/zosyn as
   this likely was a new event/infiltrate.  [**Month (only) 11**] need to consider VRE
   coverage as well.
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Cr trended up to peak of 3.0 previously. FENa
   <1%, thus pre-renal due to hypovolemia (large stool output) or
   hepatorenal syndrome. Cr improved after albumin infusion (x3), which
   argued against HRS.  Cr had normalized x 5 days but again elevated on
   [**3-23**] and is increasing.  HRS treatment was discontinued and has been
   restarted over the last several days.
   - Continue albumin for likely intravascular volume depletion and HRS
   - Continue octreotide , increase midodrine per Liver
   - Follow [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   - Renally dose meds
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # Altered mental status. Waxing and [**Doctor Last Name 282**]. Likely hepatic
   encephalopathy and SBP. Also persistently hypernatremic which is likely
   contributing to her AMS.  Has been receiving free water and Na is
   stable and mildly elevated.  Head CT on [**3-13**] neg for acute intracranial
   process.  Appears a bit more altered this morning, but is still
   responsive to voice.
   - Continue lactulose and rifaxamin (stooling well)
   - Treat hypernatremia as below
   .
   # SBP: Received Unasyn x 3 days at OSH for SBP Prophylaxis. Started
   Ceftriaxone upon arrival here. S/P diagnostic paracentesis - Second tap
   showed incr WBC with L shift, changed CTX to Zosyn on [**3-15**], per
   informal ID recs.  Vanc/Zosyn d/c
d [**3-23**] and Cipro started to complete
   total 2 week abd course. No growth on culture of peritoneal fluid.
   Bladder pressure elevated on morning of [**3-20**], pt increasingly
   uncomfortable and dyspneic. Therapeutic para done [**3-20**] to remove 2.5L
   grossly bloody fluid. Required increasing pain meds [**Date range (1) 5037**] but d/c
   [**3-23**] because no longer complaining of pain.
   - Restarted vanc/Zosyn, but will switch to Cipro after PNA resolves
   - Recheck bladder pressure today with goal < 20mmHg
   .
   # Anemia: Stable after aggressive FFP transfusions. Cause likely
   multifactorial, biggest contributor being intrabdominal bleeding after
   paracenteses, superimposed on baseline anemia of chronic disease. Also
   has low grade GI bleed (guaiac pos, not grossly bloody). Unlikely that
   the patient has DIC/hemolysis, since lab data underwhelming - low retic
   index, direct bilirubinemia, normal LDH, normal haptoglobin. GSurgery/
   transplant surgery recs: no OR.
   - Will hold off on further FFP transfusions for now
   - Daily HCT check
   - Will treat supportively with blood products. Goal Hct is 21 if
   stable, will titrate transfusions if responding appropriately to blood.
   .
   # Cirrhosis / hyperbilirubinemia / portal vein thrombosis: Patient w/
   mild transaminitis (stable) with stable thrombocytopenia, ascites, LE
   edema, hepatosplenomegaly, and elevated INR.  This is likely secondary
   to cirrhosis from alcoholism with exacerbation from chronic
   acetaminophen use.  Currently not drinking for 1 month per patient and
   husband prior to admission . Portal vein thrombosis seems acute due to
   no collateral flow in the portal circulation on CT. EGD deferred by GI
   (feels anemia more likely due to hemolysis). D/c
d midodrine/octreotide
   3/25 per liver.
   - Follow liver enzymes
 bilirubin stable and elevated
   - Continue midodrine/octreotide as above
   - minimize non-essential meds
   - Appreciate liver recs, will continue to have ongoing discussion with
   liver team regarding prognosis and likelihood of recovery.
   .
   # UTI: Positive U/A on [**3-23**], culture growing yeast. On ciprofloxacin.
   Foley changed overnight [**Date range (1) 5037**]. Will follow up on culture and adjust
   abx as needed.  Repeat culture growing yeast.
   - Continue cipro
   - Consider antifungal treatment if patient continues to decompensate,
   though no positive blood cultures
   .
   #  Thrombocytopenia. Improved. Likely secondary to liver failure and
   splenomegaly.  Evaluation for TTP and DIC difficult to interpret with
   liver failure.  Rare schistocytes on smear with elevated PTT, low
   fibrinogen, and direct hyperbilirubinemia.  However, LDH normal,
   arguing against TMA. E. coli O175:H7 neg argues against TTP/HUS.
   - Follow plt count and transfuse if plt < 10 or as needed to control
   bleeding
   .
   # Hypernatremia after initial hyponatremia: Initial hypoNa likely
   secondary to ascites and LE edema. Suspect pt became hyperNa due to TF.
   - [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   - Mix meds in D5W
   - Cont free water flushes to 300cc Q4hrs
   - Decreased D5W to 50cc/hr
   .
   #.  H/o alcohol abuse. Completed 5 days of high dose thiamine.
   - continue multivitamins, folate
   - SW consult when mental status improves
   .
   # FEN: IVF as above, replete electrolytes, TF per nutrition recs, ISS
   .
   Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots (no HSQ given elevated INR and
   thrombocytopenia), PPI
   .
   Access: PIV, PICC (placed [**3-19**])
   .
   Code: Full code.  Ongoing discussion between liver team, MICU team and
   family given patient's declining status. Will discuss intubation today,
   although not certain it will happen.
   .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 44-year-old female with a history of cirrhosis who was admitted with decompensated liver failure. The patient likely ingested ethanol and Tylenol, which worsened her condition. She has ongoing issues including altered mental status, renal failure, and coagulopathy with blood loss anemia.

The potential medical complications that can arise in this case include:

1. Altered mental status: The patient is experiencing worsening mental status, which could be due to various factors such as hepatic encephalopathy, renal failure, pneumonia, or underlying cirrhosis. Treatment includes increasing lactulose and considering other interventions.

2. Acute respiratory failure: The patient has acute respiratory failure, possibly due to new pneumonia or fluid accumulation in the lungs. There is a right-sided infiltrate seen on imaging, and the patient may require intubation and mechanical ventilation.

3. Hepato-renal syndrome/acute renal failure: The patient's BUN levels are worsening, indicating potential acute renal failure. Close monitoring of bladder pressure is necessary, and treatments like midodrine, octreotide, and albumin may be considered.

4. Coagulopathy: The patient has a flank hematoma and evidence of coagulopathy. Monitoring HCT levels and appropriate coagulation management are crucial.

5. Poor prognosis: The patient has a very poor prognosis, and regular discussions about goals of care should be held with

   This is a 44 year old female with cirrhosis presumed secondary to
   alcohol abuse and tylenol overuse who is status post a 2 week stay in
   the MICU and is transferred back with worsening renal function, mental
   status and respiratory distress.
   # Hypoxia: CXR with possible multifocal pna, but has had decreased
   oxygen requirement since narcan. She also completed 9 days of
   vanc/zosyn for SBP thus it would be unlikely that pt developed a new
   PNA. However, VRE, fungal or other ESBL organism is a possibility. Her
   abdominal girth may also be contributing to decreased chest wall
   compliance. Worsening hypoxia overnight [**3-25**], becoming more somnolent,
   able to maintain O2 sats > 90% with 100 FiO2. Improved somewhat with
   Narcan. Satting in mid-90s on 4-5L O2 NC this morning.
   - CXR shows new infiltrate
 aspiration vs edema; will treat with
   Vanc/Zosyn again as this was a new event/infiltrate. Consider VRE
   coverage as well.
   - Will try to avoid intubation as it will likely be very difficult to
   extubated; however OK to intubate if necessary per family.
   - Avoid narcotics (none given since [**3-24**])
   - Repeat bladder pressure (15 this morning)
   - Wean supplemental O2 as tolerated for goal O2 sat >92%
   # Acute renal failure: Cr trended up to peak of 3.0 previously. FENa
   <1%, thus pre-renal due to hypovolemia (large stool output) or
   hepatorenal syndrome. Cr improves after albumin infusion (5 infusions
   of 75g each so far), which argues against HRS. HRS treatment was
   discontinued and has been restarted over the last several days.
   - Continue octreotide, midodrine per Liver
   - Follow [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   - Renally dose meds
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   # Altered mental status. Waxing and [**Doctor Last Name 282**]. Likely hepatic
   encephalopathy and SBP. Also persistently hypernatremic which is likely
   contributing to her AMS.  Has been receiving free water and Na is
   stable and mildly elevated.  Head CT on [**3-13**] neg for acute intracranial
   process.  Appears a bit more altered this morning, but is still
   responsive to voice.
   - Increase lactulose and continue rifaxamin; quantify stool output to
   monitor response
   - Treat hypernatremia as below
   # SBP: Received Unasyn x 3 days at OSH for SBP Prophylaxis. Started
   Ceftriaxone upon arrival here. S/P diagnostic paracentesis - Second tap
   showed incr WBC with L shift, changed CTX to Zosyn on [**3-15**], per
   informal ID recs.  Also added Vanc. Vanc/Zosyn d/c
d [**3-23**] with
   intention of switching to Cipro, however given new infiltrate on CXR
   along with increasing resp distress Vanc and Zosyn were re-started. No
   growth on culture of peritoneal fluid. Therapeutic para done [**3-20**] to
   remove 2.5L grossly bloody fluid.
   - Continue Vanc/Zosyn for now, but will switch to Cipro after PNA
   resolves
   - Recheck bladder pressure
   # Anemia: Stable after aggressive FFP transfusions. Cause likely
   multifactorial, biggest contributor being intrabdominal bleeding after
   paracenteses, superimposed on baseline anemia of chronic disease. Also
   has low grade GI bleed (guaiac pos, not grossly bloody). Unlikely that
   the patient has DIC/hemolysis, since lab data underwhelming - low retic
   index, direct bilirubinemia, normal LDH, normal haptoglobin. GSurgery/
   transplant surgery recs: no OR.
   - Will hold off on further FFP transfusions for now
   - Daily HCT check
   - Will treat supportively with blood products. Goal Hct is 21 if
   stable, will titrate transfusions if responding appropriately to blood.
   # Cirrhosis / hyperbilirubinemia / portal vein thrombosis: Patient w/
   mild transaminitis (stable) with stable thrombocytopenia, ascites, LE
   edema, hepatosplenomegaly, and elevated INR.  This is likely secondary
   to cirrhosis from alcoholism with exacerbation from chronic
   acetaminophen use.  Currently not drinking for 1 month per patient and
   husband prior to admission . Portal vein thrombosis seems acute due to
   no collateral flow in the portal circulation on CT. EGD deferred by GI
   (feels anemia more likely due to hemolysis). D/c
d midodrine/octreotide
   3/25 per liver.
   - Follow liver enzymes
 bilirubin stable and elevated
   - Continue midodrine/octreotide as above
   - minimize non-essential meds
   - Appreciate liver recs, will continue to have ongoing discussion with
   liver team regarding prognosis and likelihood of recovery.
   # UTI: Positive U/A on [**3-23**], culture growing yeast. Foley changed
   overnight [**Date range (1) 5037**].
   - Consider antifungal treatment if patient decompensates, though no
   positive blood cultures
   #  Thrombocytopenia. Improved. Likely secondary to liver failure and
   splenomegaly.  Evaluation for TTP and DIC difficult to interpret with
   liver failure.  Rare schistocytes on smear with elevated PTT, low
   fibrinogen, and direct hyperbilirubinemia.  However, LDH normal,
   arguing against TMA. E. coli O175:H7 neg argues against TTP/HUS.
   - Follow plt count and transfuse if plt < 10 or as needed to control
   bleeding
   # Hypernatremia after initial hyponatremia: Initial hypoNa likely
   secondary to ascites and LE edema. Suspect pt became hyperNa due to TF.
   - Mix meds in D5W
   - Cont free water flushes to 300cc Q4hrs
   - Continue D5W at 100cc/hr for now, recheck lytes in afternoon.
   #.  H/o alcohol abuse. Completed 5 days of high dose thiamine.
   - continue multivitamins, folate
   - SW consult when mental status improves
   # FEN: IVF as above, replete electrolytes, TF per nutrition recs, ISS

   thrombocytopenia), PPI
